PLS100.name: Introduction to American Politics
PLS100.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS100.description: The policymaking process in national government, with emphasis on political participation, the presidency, Congress, Supreme Court, bureaucracy, and civil rights and civil liberties.

PLS140.name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
PLS140.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS140.description: Comparative analysis of political systems in first, second, and third-world countries. Alternative methods for comparative cross-cultural analyses of political systems.

PLS160.name: Introduction to International Relations
PLS160.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS160.description: Dynamics of conflict and cooperation. Processes of foreign policy decision making. Major international economic issues. Basic future trends. Primary analytical approaches for studying world politics.

PLS170.name: Introduction to Political Philosophy
PLS170.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS170.description: Basic questions of political philosophy as considered from ancient to modern times. Primary focus on the origins, defense, and radical critiques of modern liberal democracy.

PLS200.name: Introduction to Political Science
PLS200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS200.description: The science of politics. Theory construction, model building, empirical testing, and inductive inference. Examples from American, international and comparative politics.

PLS201.name: Introduction to Methods of Political Analysis
PLS201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS201.description: Philosophy of social science. Principles of research design, measurement, hypothesis testing, measures of association, cross tabulations, and regression analysis.

PLS202.name: Introduction to Data Analytics and the Social Sciences
PLS202.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS202.description: Approaches to data analysis in the social sciences. Computational tools for data collection and visualization across various digital sources, including text or social media.

PLS302.name: Urban Politics
PLS302.description: Structure and processes of American urban politics. Relationship of cities to U.S. federal system. Interstate variations. Policy focus on public education, crime, social welfare, and economic development.

PLS304.name: Minority Politics
PLS304.description: Minority groups and the political process in the United States. Civil rights movements, political organizations, legal decisions, political participation, and legislative politics.

PLS310.name: Public Administration and Policy Making
PLS310.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS310.description: Role of public bureaucracy in the U.S. Theories of administrative behavior and the impact of hierarchy on policymaking. Relations with the president, Congress, interest groups, and the public. Administrative functions, responsiveness, and ethics.

PLS313.name: American Public Policy
PLS313.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS313.description: Political and economic concepts for evaluating the consequences of government decision making. Issues of problem identification, policy adoption, and implementation affecting program evaluation.

PLS320.name: Judicial Politics
PLS320.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS320.description: Analysis of the structure and functions of judicial systems. Organization, administration, and politics of judicial bureaucracies. Roles of judges, juries, counsel, litigants, and interest groups in the adjudication process.
PLS320.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

PLS321.name: Constitutional Law
PLS321.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS321.description: U.S. Supreme Court policy making and its effect on issues of current importance, including First Amendment freedoms, due process, race relations, sex discrimination, and privacy.
PLS321.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

PLS322.name: Comparative Legal Systems
PLS322.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS322.description: Cross-national study of common law and civil law systems. Judicial review and selection of judges. Models of judicial decision-making. High court-low court relations. Role of courts in society.

PLS324.name: Congress
PLS324.description: The design of Congress. Rules, structures, and procedures affecting policy making. Impact of regular elections on legislative behavior.

PLS325.name: The Presidency
PLS325.description: Role of the president in the U.S. political system. Constitutional questions, presidential selection, presidential power, interbranch relations, and presidential policy making.

PLS333.name: Public Opinion and Political Behavior
PLS333.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS333.description: Role of public opinion in political systems and its impact on the political process. Group differences, political socialization, development and change of political attitudes and behavior patterns. Methods of studying public opinion.

PLS334.name: Campaigns and Elections
PLS334.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS334.description: The nominating process. Recruitment of candidates and the formation of electoral coalitions. Analysis of election results. Trends in electoral support for officeholders and parties.

PLS342.name: Comparative Political Economy
PLS342.description: Democratic politics and the linkages among political, social, and economic conceptions of equality in developed and developing countries.

PLS344.name: Politics of Developing Areas
PLS344.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS344.description: Politics of modernization, democratic and authoritarian regimes, and class and ethnicity in developing countries.

PLS345.name: Religion and World Politics
PLS345.description: Comparative analysis of the role of religion in politics across world regions. Discussion of major theories and topics in relation to religion-state relations.

PLS346.name: Middle East Politics
PLS346.description: Political history, political institutions, political actors, and political culture in the Arab countries of North Africa and the Middle East, as well as Turkey, Israel, and Iran.

PLS347.name: Democratic Regimes
PLS347.description: Democratization, democratic consolidation, political institutions, and economic development in Africa, Latin America, Asia, Eastern Europe, and the Middle East.

PLS351.name: African Politics
PLS351.description: Political institutions and governmental processes in Sub-Saharan Africa.

PLS354.name: Politics of Asia
PLS354.semester: Fall of even years, Spring of even years
PLS354.description: Political institutions, political actors, and policy-making processes in selected Asian countries.

PLS356.name: Politics of Europe and the European Union
PLS356.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
PLS356.description: Governmental institutions and processes, political socialization, and political culture in Western Europe and the European Union.

PLS357.name: Politics of English Speaking Democracies
PLS357.description: Political institutions, political actors, and political culture in Britain, Australia, or Canada.

PLS358.name: Politics of the U.S.S.R. and Its Successor States
PLS358.description: Political history, communist ideology, state institutions, and political processes in the Soviet Union and its successor states.

PLS362.name: American Foreign Policy and National Security
PLS362.description: Theories of foreign policy making. Factors shaping foreign policy in various countries. Current and recurrent problems in foreign policy making.
PLS362.prerequisite: (PLS 160 or concurrently) or (MC 220 or concurrently) or (MC 221 or concurrently)

PLS363.name: International and Domestic Political Conflict
PLS363.description: Civil war, conflict, and conflict resolution in the international system.

PLS364.name: Politics of the United Nations and International Organizations
PLS364.description: History and evolution. League of Nations, United Nations. Growth and role of regional, specialized, and non-governmental organizations. Impact of new states. Politics, functions, and problems.

PLS371.name: Classical Political Philosophy
PLS371.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS371.description: Examination of major themes in classical political philosophy as represented by such Greek and Roman philosophers as Plato, Aristotle, or Cicero.

PLS372.name: Modern Political Philosophy
PLS372.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS372.description: Major themes of modern political philosophy as represented by such thinkers as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Rousseau, Marx, and Nietzsche.

PLS377.name: American Political Thought
PLS377.description: Major themes of American political thought. Topics may include the founding of the U.S., naturalism, race relations, or progressivism.

PLS392.name: Special Topics in Political Science
PLS392.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS392.description: Issues and problems in contemporary political science.
PLS392.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Political Science or in the College of Social Science or in the Interdisciplinary Studies in Social Science Major or in the Political Science Major or in the Political Science-Prelaw Major or in the Public Policy Major or in the World Politics Major or approval of department.

PLS397.name: Analyzing and Visualizing Data in Politics
PLS397.description: Exploration and evaluation of political science theories or public policies through empirical analysis; approaches to data and graphical analysis in the political sciences; studies of prominent or emerging political science and policy data sources.

PLS422.name: Seminar in Political Science (W)
PLS422.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS422.description: Variable topics including legislative behavior, policy analysis, political development, human rights, international conflict, foreign policy, international political economy, and constitutionalism.
PLS422.prerequisite: (PLS 201) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PLS441.name: Islam and World Politics
PLS441.description: Manifestations of political Islam within key Muslim countries such as Turkey, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Pakistan. Use of political Islam by states and groups as an instrument to advance their international goals.
PLS441.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

PLS442.name: Social Science Data Analytics Applications
PLS442.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS442.description: Application of computational tools for data collection and visualization to various topics in social science research.

PLS481H.name: Undergraduate Research Seminar
PLS481H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS481H.description: Advanced research seminar for students in the political science program.
PLS481H.prerequisite: PLS 200 or concurrently or approval of department

PLS490H.name: Honors Internship
PLS490H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS490H.description: Supervised participation in research or teaching.

PLS491H.name: Senior Honors Thesis
PLS491H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS491H.description: Original research and writing under direction of a faculty member.

PLS494.name: Field Experience in Political Science
PLS494.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS494.description: Supervised field work in several areas of study. It may involve internships with non-profit organizations or public agencies, or participation in survey research, political campaigns, or petition drives.

PLS495.name: Independent Study
PLS495.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS495.description: Individual research and reading supervised by a faculty member.

PLS800.name: Proseminar: Political Theory and Research Methods
PLS800.description: Issues in the accumulation of knowledge about political phenomena. Approaches to the verification of hypotheses. Alternative theoretical conceptions in study of politics.

PLS801.name: Quantitative Techniques in Public Policy and Political Science I
PLS801.description: Foundations of research methodology. Applications of data in public policy and political science. Individual research projects.
PLS801.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Political Science or approval of department.

PLS802.name: Quantitative Techniques in Public Policy and Political Science II
PLS802.description: Linear and nonlinear models applied to public policy and political science data. Individualized research projects.
PLS802.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Political Science or approval of department.

PLS803.name: Political Thought
PLS803.description: Major political philosophers. Major themes of political philosophy. Consideration of the relationship between political philosophy and other fields of study in political science.

PLS809.name: Proseminar in Formal Theory
PLS809.description: Formal models in understanding politics. Topics may include game theory, spatial modeling, social choice theory, public choice theory, and dynamic modeling. Theoretical issues and research applications.
PLS809.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Political Science Major or approval of department.

PLS811.name: Proseminar in Policy Analysis
PLS811.description: Economic and political techniques for analyzing public policies. Utility and limitations of these techniques and their use and abuse in public policy analysis.

PLS820.name: Proseminar in American Politics
PLS820.description: The major subfields of American politics. Political behavior within institutions and mass political behavior.

PLS821.name: State Government and Politics
PLS821.description: Research literature on state government. Interstate differences. Parties, elections, governors, state legislatures, bureaucracy, interest groups, and policy outcomes.

PLS822.name: Urban Government and Politics
PLS822.description: Research literature on urban government. Structure, process, and policy issues. Intergovernmental relations and fiscal interdependencies.

PLS826.name: International Development: Theory and Practice
PLS826.description: Evolution of international development theory across disciplines. Changing conceptualizations, measurements, processes and effects of development and poverty. Ethnicity, social class, gender, and community influences on socioeconomic processes. Current issues, concerns, and strategic alternatives.

PLS828.name: Public Opinion and Political Behavior
PLS828.description: The acquisition and change of political attitudes. The relationship between political attitudes and political behavior. Methods and problems of measuring political attitudes.

PLS850.name: Proseminar in Comparative Politics
PLS850.description: Research literature in a subfield of comparative politics. Methods, approaches, and purposes.

PLS854.name: Comparative Political Institutions
PLS854.description: Political institutions from a comparative perspective. Topics may include electoral systems, political parties, presidential vs. parliamentary systems, representation, federalism, and constitutional engineering.

PLS857.name: Parties and Elections
PLS857.description: Origin, organization, and behavior of political parties in advanced industrial societies. Structure and transformation of party systems. Role of issues and elections in party systems. Parties in developing societies.

PLS860.name: Proseminar in International Relations
PLS860.description: Theoretical perspectives and analytical approaches to a subfield of international relations.

PLS870.name: Proseminar in Political Thought
PLS870.description: Survey of major issues or themes in political philosophy.

PLS871.name: Classical Political Philosophy
PLS871.description: Study of one or more major figures or thinkers in ancient or medieval political philosophy.

PLS872.name: Modern Political Philosophy
PLS872.description: Study of one or more major figures or thinkers in modern political philosophy.

PLS877.name: American Political Thought
PLS877.description: Study of one or more major concepts or thinkers in American political thought.

PLS884.name: Proseminar on Political Institutions and Public Choice
PLS884.description: Theories of political institutions, with particular emphasis on the U.S. Possible topics include models of rational action in electoral, legislative, and bureaucratic institutions and problems of majority rule, collective action, and social welfare.

PLS900.name: Research Seminar in Political Methodology
PLS900.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS900.description: Advanced topics in political methodology. Individual research projects.

PLS910.name: Research Seminar in Public Policy and Public Administration
PLS910.description: Specialized topics in public administration or public policy.

PLS920.name: Research Seminar in American Politics
PLS920.description: Intensive study of one subfield of American politics. Critical evaluation of the literature.

PLS950.name: Research Seminar in Comparative Politics
PLS950.description: Intensive study of one subfield of comparative politics. Critical evaluation of the literature.

PLS960.name: Research Seminar in International Politics
PLS960.description: Intensive study of one subfield of international politics. Critical evaluation of the literature.

PLS970.name: Research Seminar in Political Thought
PLS970.description: Intensive study of one subfield of political philosophy.

PLS980.name: Research Seminar in Formal Theory
PLS980.description: Intensive study of one formal modeling technique used in political science research.

PLS990.name: Topics in Professional Development
PLS990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PLS990.description: Professionalization for Ph.D. students, including seminars on dissertation writing, graduate student teaching, and other aspects of professional development.
PLS990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Political Science.

PLS993.name: Readings in Political Science
PLS993.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS993.description: Supervised reading in a subfield of political science, public administration, or public policy.

PLS999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PLS999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PLS999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Political Science major.
